intro: Brassica oleracea subvar. cymosa, commonly known as cauliflower, is a cool-season crop characterized by its dense, compact inflorescence. The plant produces a head of tightly packed white or green flower buds, which are harvested before they open. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family and is closely related to other cruciferous vegetables like broccoli and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of 40–80 cm and has dark green, lobed leaves. Its botanical structure supports its use in both culinary and nutritional contexts.
